political_events.description: Turkish Armed Forces relocate the Tomb of Süleyman Shah from Syria due to ISIS threat; widely discussed domestically as a major military decision.
AKP loses parliamentary majority for the first time since 2002, resulting in a hung parliament.
ISIS suicide bombing kills 33 activists in Suruç; triggers widespread protests and a major escalation in security operations.
Turkey’s deadliest terror attack, killing over 100 people at a peace rally; attributed to ISIS.
AKP regains majority after failed coalition negotiations.
Turkish forces down a Russian Su-24 near the Syrian border, triggering a major diplomatic crisis.
Davutoğlu resigns after internal AKP tensions; Binali Yıldırım becomes the new Prime Minister.
EU–Turkey deal negotiated to limit irregular migration; becomes binding on 20 March.
A faction within the military attempts to overthrow the government; over 250 people are killed; coup is defeated within hours.
Following the coup attempt, Turkey declares a nationwide state of emergency, expanding executive powers.
Turkey launches a cross-border military operation into northern Syria against ISIS and YPG positions.
Turkey narrowly passes a referendum replacing the parliamentary system with an executive presidency.

political_events.event: OSCE and EU Criticisms of Referendum
political_events.description: International observers raise concerns about voting irregularities and democratic standards.
First elections under the new presidential system; Erdoğan re-elected.
CHP leader Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu begins a 450 km march from Ankara to Istanbul after MP Enis Berberoğlu is jailed.
The 'Justice March' culminates with one of Turkey’s largest opposition rallies of the decade.
State of Emergency extensions continue with broad administrative and judicial measures.
Turkey strongly condemns the KRG referendum; threatens border closures and sanctions.
Turkish Armed Forces and allied Syrian groups continue their ground campaign, tightening control around Afrin.
Afrin city center falls under Turkish control; major political and media reactions follow.
President Erdoğan announces early elections for June 24, accelerating Turkey’s transition to presidential system.
Erdoğan wins presidential election; AKP–MHP alliance secures parliamentary majority; Turkey officially moves to the executive presidency.
Prime Ministry is abolished; ministries are restructured; Erdoğan appoints Berat Albayrak as Minister of Treasury and Finance.
Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi is killed in the Saudi consulate; Turkey launches an international diplomatic offensive.
Supreme Election Council orders a rerun of Istanbul mayoral election; widely criticized by domestic and international observers.
Ekrem İmamoğlu wins by a large margin, marking a major shift in Turkish urban politics.
Opposition wins major cities including Istanbul and Ankara; ruling party disputes Istanbul results.
Repeated recounts and legal challenges intensify political tensions; YSK reviews AKP objections.
İmamoğlu wins rerun by a large margin, becoming Erdoğan’s top political rival.

political_events.event: Syria Safe Zone Negotiations with the U.S.
political_events.description: Turkey and the U.S. initiate talks on establishing a safe zone in northern Syria to contain YPG forces.
Turkey launches military operations in northeast Syria targeting YPG; significant international reactions follow.

political_events.event: Formation of New Parties by Former AKP Leaders
political_events.description: Ali Babacan and Ahmet Davutoğlu accelerate efforts to form DEVA and Future Party, signaling internal fragmentation.
Multiple earthquakes and floods across Turkey prompt national discussions on preparedness and infrastructure.
Turkey confirms its first COVID-19 case; strict public health measures and curfews begin shortly after.
Council of State annuls museum status; Hagia Sophia reopened as a mosque, drawing global reactions.

political_events.event: Berat Albayrak Resigns as Finance Minister
political_events.description: Albayrak announces resignation via Instagram; triggers major cabinet and economic policy shifts.
Murat Uysal is dismissed; Naci Ağbal appointed CBRT governor, signaling a return to orthodox policies.
EU leaders discuss sanctions over Eastern Mediterranean drilling activities.
Severe wildfires devastate Antalya, Muğla, and other regions; government criticized for inadequate aerial firefighting capacity.

political_events.event: Major Cabinet Reshuffles in Economic Team
political_events.description: Changes in deputy ministers and bureaucratic leadership signal growing instability in economic governance.
First court hearings for allegedly insulting state officials after the 2019 election annulment.

political_events.event: Electricity and Natural Gas Price Hikes
political_events.description: Government announces steep energy price increases; strong public backlash emerges as cost of living rises.

political_events.event: Turkey Positions Itself as Mediator in Russia–Ukraine Crisis
political_events.description: Ankara calls for diplomacy and hosts multiple meetings as tensions escalate ahead of the invasion.

political_events.event: Opposition Alliance (Table of Six) Gains Visibility
political_events.description: Opposition coalition releases strengthened parliamentary system proposal; coordination increases ahead of 2023 elections.

political_events.event: Sweden and Finland NATO Application Tensions
political_events.description: Turkey initially blocks NATO accession talks over security concerns, demanding action against PKK-linked groups.
Turkey launches large-scale airstrikes on northern Syria and Iraq following Istanbul attack.
İmamoğlu sentenced to 2 years 7 months and issued a political ban (pending appeal). Major protests erupt.
7.8 and 7.5 magnitude earthquakes devastate 11 provinces; millions displaced.
Erdoğan wins re-election; AKP-MHP alliance maintains majority.
AKP and MHP renew efforts to draft a new constitution; opposition disputes priorities.
Parties launch campaigns for March 2024 municipal elections, with Istanbul and Ankara as major battlegrounds.
Government reiterates desire for a new civilian constitution; opposition criticizes timing and priorities.
One-year anniversary of the 2023 earthquakes prompts public scrutiny of rebuilding progress and safety standards.
CHP wins Istanbul, Ankara, and many new municipalities; AKP’s worst local performance in decades.

political_events.event: Fall of the Assad Regime and Formation of Syrian Caretaker Government
political_events.description: Opposition forces capture Damascus; Bashar al-Assad’s regime collapses and a provisional caretaker government is formed, marking a major turning point in the Syrian conflict.
İmamoğlu detained on 19 March and formally arrested on 23 March 2025. Nationwide protests, largest since Gezi.

economic_events.description: TRY begins a year-long depreciation trend due to global USD strength and domestic political uncertainty.

economic_events.event: Central Bank Pressure on Interest Rates
economic_events.description: Political pressure escalates on the CBRT to cut rates before the June election; debates over independence intensify.
The hung parliament outcome leads to uncertainty; TRY drops sharply and risk premiums rise.
China’s market crash impacts Turkey; capital outflows increase and TRY hits record lows against USD.
AKP’s regained majority briefly strengthens markets and reduces volatility.
Refugee deal negotiations include EU commitments for financial assistance, influencing budget expectations.
Lira hits new lows against USD and EUR amid political uncertainty and global dollar strength.
Government expands credit guarantees to boost lending, temporarily stimulating growth.
Food and energy prices surge, contributing to rising concerns over monetary policy independence.
Dramatic collapse of the Turkish lira amid U.S. sanctions and structural imbalances; USD/TRY spikes above 7.0.
CBRT raises rates sharply despite political pressure, stabilizing markets temporarily.
Turkey reaches its highest inflation level since the early 2000s.
TRY experiences sudden volatility amid political uncertainty and concerns over reserves.
New package aims to stabilize markets but receives mixed reactions from economists.
New governor Murat Uysal cuts rates significantly, triggering debate on overheating and inflation risk.
Tourism collapses; FX reserves drained to defend the lira.
Lira surpasses 7.30 per USD amid concerns about reserves and geopolitical tensions.

economic_events.event: Central Bank Governor Naci Ağbal Fired
economic_events.description: Ağbal is removed days after raising interest rates; markets shocked; TRY depreciates sharply.

economic_events.event: New CBRT Governor Continues Rate Cuts Signaling
economic_events.description: Lower-interest rhetoric increases market concerns about unorthodox economic policies.
Input costs and global commodity prices push inflation into double digits; real wages erode.
Lira depreciates rapidly; USD/TRY surpasses 12, then 13; inflation accelerates.
FX-protected deposit scheme (KKM) launched to halt dollarization.
Cost-of-living crisis accelerates amid the consequences of 2021 monetary easing.
FX-protected deposit scheme (KKM) slows the crash but volatility persists; reserves under pressure.
Official inflation reaches its highest point in over two decades; food and rent costs surge.
Mehmet Şimşek becomes finance minister; shift toward tight monetary policy begins.
CB hikes policy rate to 25%, then 30%, 35%, 40% through late 2023.
CB holds policy rate at 50% through late 2024; inflation begins gradually slowing.
Tight credit conditions, tax increases, and spending controls deepen the short-term slowdown.

economic_events.event: Emergency MONETARY Response to İmamoğlu Arrest
economic_events.description: CB holds extraordinary meeting, hikes overnight rate, deploys FX reserves to stabilise markets.

refugee_migration_events.description: Images of Alan Kurdi trigger global humanitarian outcry; EU debates asylum policies.
EU's Facility for Refugees in Turkey created to manage €6bn support package.
TRY weakens amid global volatility and domestic security concerns.
Statement agreed on 18 March 2016; becomes operational on 20 March.
Turkey and EU reach formal agreement aiming to control irregular migration; includes financial aid and visa liberalization roadmap.
386 migrants returned from Greek islands to Turkey in April 2016.
Returns fall sharply; containment becomes main effect.
EU Council approves second €3bn FRIT package.
EU reports ~€4.2bn committed; slower project delivery than expected.
Turkey opens border toward Greece; clashes at Evros; EU suspends returns.
EU commits another €3bn to support refugees and host communities.
As the Taliban takes Kabul, public debate intensifies over potential new refugee flows into Turkey.
EU releases major tranche for cash-card assistance program.
Millions displaced across 11 provinces, including large Syrian populations.
EU debates new funding mechanism to replace FRIT after 2023.
EU states pledge new multi-country support including Turkey’s refugee programs.
